issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: The problem described is an issue which will never be fixed.
resolution.name: Won't Fix

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Run instance request able to exceed resource limitations for vmware cluster

10.111.1.99	VMWARE	ESXI-5.0	64	REPO	[NC01]

comments.body: I'm assuming this got into this state while issuing back to back requests. Not sure of the timing, but guessing the 2nd requests was done during the 'pending' state of the first instance. In this case, the instance could have been in pending for tens of minutes.

I was able to reproduce this today. It looks like the window may be during the caching phase, and as shown from the CLI output the repeated requests are both rejected and accepted? 
I was not able to reproduce this with a few attempts using a 1G linux image. I'm using a large 15gb+ Windows image now and have been able to reproduce on the first attempt. 
Thanks,
-M

Hey, [~mclark], how certain are you that this is a VMware-specific problem? Obviously, that's where you encountered it, but do you recall performing similar actions on a KVM cluster without running into resource overallocation? The reason I ask is that both clusters look the same to the CLC, which is the one doing the gating and accounting for resources. I am not saying it cannot be a VMware-specific problem, but if it is easy to try the same experiment on a KVM cluster, that may help us focus our investigation better. Thanks!

[~dmitrii], I tried with the KVM cluster and image in the same cloud several times but could not reproduce. There is a difference with the # of nodes. 2 in the vmware cluster and 1 in the kvm. Will try with a second kvm node and update. 
Thanks,
-M

Quick update...
 I as not able to reproduce with a KVM cluster using 2 nodes, after several tries using an emi built from the same image. Might be that there is just a smaller window for this to occur w/ KVM?
Thanks,
-M
This ticket relates to VMware. See https://www.eucalyptus.com/eucalyptus-cloud/iaas/compatibility for latest hypervisor compatibility by version.
